title: Susan Wojcicki
content:
{{short description|American business executive (born 1968)}} {{Infobox person | name = Susan Wojcicki | image = Susan Wojcicki (29393944130) (cropped).jpg | caption = Wojcicki in September 2016 | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1968|7|5}} | birth_place = [[Santa Clara County, California]], U.S. | death_date = | death_place = | spouse = {{marriage|Dennis Troper|1998}} | children = 5 | relatives = [[Esther Wojcicki]] (mother)
[[Stanley Wojcicki]] (father)
[[Anne Wojcicki]] (sister)
[[Janina Wójcicka Hoskins]] (grandmother)
[[Franciszek Wójcicki]] (grandfather) | signature = Susan Wojcicki signature.svg | occupation = Business executive }} '''Susan Diane Wojcicki''' ({{IPAc-en|w|ʊ|ˈ|tʃ|ɪ|t|s|k|i}} {{respell|wuu|CHITS|kee}};{{YouTube|a07s88y7f-k|"#DearMe: Susan Wojcicki, CEO of YouTube"}} born July 5, 1968) is a Polish-American business executive who is the [[CEO]] of [[YouTube]]. Her net worth was estimated at $765 million in 2022.{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/susan-wojcicki|title=#34 Susan Wojcicki|website=Forbes|access-date=2022-07-09|language=en|archive-date=2021-08-23|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210823074616/https://www.forbes.com/profile/susan-wojcicki|url-status=live}} Wojcicki has worked in the [[technology industry]] for over 20 years.{{Cite web|date=2019-08-10|title=YouTube's Susan Wojcicki: 'Where's the line of free speech – are you removing voices that should be heard?'|url=http://www.theguardian.com/technology/2019/aug/10/youtube-susan-wojcicki-ceo-where-line-removing-voices-heard|access-date=2021-01-16|website=the Guardian|language=en|archive-date=2021-01-19|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210119032309/https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2019/aug/10/youtube-susan-wojcicki-ceo-where-line-removing-voices-heard|url-status=live}}{{Cite web|last=Connley|first=Courtney|date=2019-08-20|title=YouTube CEO Susan Wojcicki: Here's what to say when men are talking over you at a meeting|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2019/08/20/susan-wojcicki-what-to-say-when-men-are-talking-over-you-at-a-meeting.html|access-date=2021-01-16|website=CNBC|language=en|archive-date=2020-11-09|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201109180450/https://www.cnbc.com/2019/08/20/susan-wojcicki-what-to-say-when-men-are-talking-over-you-at-a-meeting.html|url-status=live}} She became involved in the creation of [[Google]] in 1998 when its founders first set up a garage office in the home of her parents, [[Esther Wojcicki|Esther]] and [[Stanley Wojcicki]]. She worked as Google's first marketing manager in 1999, and later led the company's online advertising business and original video service. After observing the success of YouTube, she suggested that Google should buy it; the deal was approved for $1.65 billion in 2006. She was apppointed CEO of YouTube in 2014. ==Early life== Susan Diane Wojcicki was born in [[Santa Clara County, California]], on July 5, 1968,{{cite web |url=http://www.familytreelegends.com/records/39461?c=search&first=Susan&last=Wojcicki |title=California Births, 1905 - 1995 |publisher=Familytreelegends.com |access-date=March 15, 2014 |archive-date=June 4, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130604041118/http://www.familytreelegends.com/records/39461?c=search&first=Susan&last=Wojcicki |url-status=live }} the daughter of [[Esther Wojcicki]], an American journalist, and [[Stanley Wojcicki]], a Polish physics professor at [[Stanford University]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/06/18/how-the-wojcickis-parents-raised-23andme-founder-youtube-ceo.html|title=How Anne and Susan Wojcicki's parents raised the founder of 23andMe and the CEO of YouTube|last=Clifford|first=Catherine|date=2018-06-18|website=CNBC|language=en|access-date=2019-05-14|archive-date=2020-01-03|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200103010613/https://www.cnbc.com/2018/06/18/how-the-wojcickis-parents-raised-23andme-founder-youtube-ceo.html|url-status=live}} Her maternal grandparents were [[Russian-Jewish]] immigrants.{{cite web|last1=Tramiel|first1=Preeva|title=Esther Wojcicki: A Jewish mother of the tech revolution|url=https://jwa.org/blog/esther-wojcicki-jewish-mother-of-tech-revolution|access-date=1 August 2017|archive-date=19 January 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170119122055/https://jwa.org/blog/esther-wojcicki-jewish-mother-of-tech-revolution|url-status=live}} Her paternal grandfather, [[Franciszek Wójcicki]], was a Polish politician who had been elected MP during the [[1947 Polish legislative election]].{{Citation|title=Franciszek Wójcicki|date=2018-02-28|url=https://pl.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Franciszek_W%C3%B3jcicki&oldid=52616862|work=Wikipedia, wolna encyklopedia|language=pl|access-date=2020-01-07|archive-date=2022-05-04|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220504010518/https://pl.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Franciszek_W%C3%B3jcicki&oldid=52616862|url-status=live}} Her paternal grandmother, [[Janina Wójcicka Hoskins]], was a Polish-American librarian at the [[Library of Congress]] and was responsible for building the largest collection of Polish material in the U.S.{{Cite journal|last=Zalewski|first=Wojciech|date=2011-10-01|title=Janina Wójcicka Hoskins (1912–1996): Portrait of an Esteemed Librarian|journal=Slavic & East European Information Resources|volume=12|issue=4|pages=224–236|doi=10.1080/15228886.2011.623117|s2cid=144135260|issn=1522-8886}} She has two sisters: Janet, a doctor of anthropology and epidemiology,{{cite web|last1=Sellers|first1=Patricia|title=Before Google, the Wojcicki girls learned from Mom|url=http://fortune.com/2012/02/01/before-google-the-wojcicki-girls-learned-from-mom/|website=Fortune.com|access-date=16 December 2014|archive-date=7 February 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170207040836/http://fortune.com/2012/02/01/before-google-the-wojcicki-girls-learned-from-mom/|url-status=live}} and [[Anne Wojcicki|Anne]], an entrepreneur who is the co-founder and CEO of [[23andMe]].[https://www.cnbc.com/2019/05/08/i-raised-2-successful-ceos-and-a-doctor-here-is-one-if-the-biggest-mistakes-parents-make.html I raised 2 successful CEOs and a doctor—here’s one of the biggest mistakes I see parents making] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190905230316/https://www.cnbc.com/2019/05/08/i-raised-2-successful-ceos-and-a-doctor-here-is-one-if-the-biggest-mistakes-parents-make.html |date=2019-09-05 }}, Esther Wojcicki, Published Wed, May 8, 2019, cnbc.com.{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/06/18/how-the-wojcickis-parents-raised-23andme-founder-youtube-ceo.html|title=How Anne and Susan Wojcicki's parents raised the founder of 23andMe and the CEO of YouTube|last=Clifford|first=Catherine|date=2018-06-18|website=CNBC|language=en|access-date=2019-10-28|archive-date=2020-01-03|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200103010613/https://www.cnbc.com/2018/06/18/how-the-wojcickis-parents-raised-23andme-founder-youtube-ceo.html|url-status=live}} Wojcicki grew up on the Stanford campus, where mathematical scientist [[George Dantzig]] was her neighbor. She attended [[Gunn High School]] in [[Palo Alto, California]], and wrote for the school newspaper.{{cite magazine |url=http://fortune.com/2012/02/01/before-google-the-wojcicki-girls-learned-from-mom/ |title=Before Google, the Wojcicki girls learned from Mom |magazine=Fortune Magazine |date=February 1, 2012 |first=Patricia |last=Sellers |access-date=October 4, 2014 |archive-date=February 7, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170207040836/http://fortune.com/2012/02/01/before-google-the-wojcicki-girls-learned-from-mom/ |url-status=live }} Her first business was selling "spice ropes" door-to-door at the age of 11. A humanities major in college, she took her first computer science class as a senior. She studied history and literature at [[Harvard University]] and graduated with honors in 1990. She originally planned on getting a Ph.D. in economics and pursuing a career in academia, but changed her plans when she discovered an interest in technology. She also received her MS in economics in 1993 from the [[University of California, Santa Cruz]], and an MBA in 1998 from the [[UCLA Anderson School of Management]].{{cite news |url=http://www.mercurynews.com/ci_17286427 |title=Susan Wojcicki: The most important Googler you've never heard of |newspaper=San Jose Mercury News |date=February 7, 2011 |first=Mike |last=Swift |access-date=October 4, 2014 |archive-date=August 17, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160817045904/http://www.mercurynews.com/ci_17286427 |url-status=live }} ==Career== [[File:Mateusz Morawiecki wraz z Susan Wojcicki prezesem YouTube odwiedzili Centrum Nauki Kopernik.jpg|thumb|left|Wojcicki with Polish Prime Minister [[Mateusz Morawiecki]] in [[Warsaw]] in November 2018]] In September 1998, the same month that [[Google]] was incorporated, its co-founders [[Larry Page]] and [[Sergey Brin]] set up office in Wojcicki's parents' garage in [[Menlo Park, California]].{{cite news|last=|first=|date=2012-04-02|title=Our history in depth – Company – Google|newspaper=|url=http://www.google.com/intl/en/about/company/history/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120402210041/http://www.google.com/intl/en/about/company/history/|url-status=live|access-date=2018-11-07|archive-date=2012-04-02}} Before becoming Google's first marketing manager in 1999, Wojcicki worked in marketing at [[Intel Corporation]] in [[Santa Clara, California]],{{cite magazine |url=http://www.fastcompany.com/3033957/the-woman-behind-the-superlatives-three-things-you-need-to-know-about-susan-wojcicki |title=The Woman Behind the Superlatives: Three Things You Need to Know About Susan Wojcicki |magazine=The Fast Company |date=August 6, 2014 |first=Nicole |last=Laporte |access-date=October 4, 2014 |archive-date=August 18, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160818215114/http://www.fastcompany.com/3033957/the-woman-behind-the-superlatives-three-things-you-need-to-know-about-susan-wojcicki |url-status=live }} and was a management consultant at [[Bain & Company]] and R.B. Webber & Company.{{cite magazine |url=http://ideas.time.com/contributor/susan-wojcicki/ |title=Susan Wojcicki |magazine=Time |access-date=October 4, 2014 |archive-date=March 14, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170314183002/http://ideas.time.com/contributor/susan-wojcicki/ |url-status=live }} At Google, she worked on the initial viral marketing programs, helped create the company's longtime logo with designer [[Ruth Kedar]], and spearheaded the first [[Google Doodle]]s.{{cite web|url=http://www.anderson.ucla.edu/alumni/100-inspirational-alumni/susan-wojcicki-inspirational-100-alumna|title=Susan Wojcicki - "Inspirational 100" Alumna|publisher=UCLA Anderson School of Management|access-date=October 4, 2014|archive-date=March 4, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170304201849/http://www.anderson.ucla.edu/alumni/100-inspirational-alumni/susan-wojcicki-inspirational-100-alumna|url-status=live}}{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NCvdUbeWS60C&q=susan+wojcicki+At+Google%2C+she+worked+on+the+initial+viral+marketing+programs%2C+as+well+as+the+first+Google+Doodles&pg=PA15|title=Think Quarterly: Innovation (US)|language=en|access-date=2020-10-20|archive-date=2021-05-15|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210515075745/https://books.google.com/books?id=NCvdUbeWS60C&q=susan+wojcicki+At+Google,+she+worked+on+the+initial+viral+marketing+programs,+as+well+as+the+first+Google+Doodles&pg=PA15|url-status=live}} She also co-developed and launched [[Google Images|Google Image Search]] with engineer Huican Zhu. In 2003, Wojcicki was the first product manager of one of Google's seminal advertising products—[[Google AdSense|AdSense]].{{Cite web|title=Profile Of Susan Wojcicki: Mother Of AdSense|url=https://searchengineland.com/profile-of-susan-wojcicki-mother-of-adsense-11629|date=2007-07-05|website=Search Engine Land|access-date=2020-05-31|archive-date=2020-05-16|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200516121341/https://searchengineland.com/profile-of-susan-wojcicki-mother-of-adsense-11629|url-status=live}} She earned the Google Founders' Award in recognition for this work.{{Cite web|url=https://usatoday30.usatoday.com/tech/techinvestor/corporatenews/2007-07-04-google-wojcicki_N.htm|title=The house that helped build Google - USATODAY.com|website=usatoday30.usatoday.com|access-date=2019-11-23|archive-date=2019-09-26|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190926095339/https://usatoday30.usatoday.com/tech/techinvestor/corporatenews/2007-07-04-google-wojcicki_N.htm|url-status=live}} Wojcicki was subsequently promoted to Google's senior vice president of Advertising & Commerce, and oversaw the company's advertising and analytic products, including [[AdWords]], [[AdSense]], [[DoubleClick]], and [[Google Analytics]]. [[YouTube]], then a small start-up, was successfully competing with Google's Google Video service, overseen by Wojcicki.{{cite news|last=Gustin|first=Sam|title=Google Ad Chief Susan Wojcicki: 'The Book Isn't Finished'|url=https://www.wired.com/epicenter/2011/05/susan-wojcicki/|access-date=10 September 2011|newspaper=Wired.com|date=3 May 2011|archive-date=6 September 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110906185040/http://www.wired.com/epicenter/2011/05/susan-wojcicki/|url-status=live}} She recommended and subsequently managed the $1.65 billion purchase of YouTube in 2006, as well as the $3.1 billion purchase of [[DoubleClick]] in 2007.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bizjournals.com/bizwomen/news/latest-news/2017/08/wojcicki-emo-could-deter-women-from-tech-careers.html?page=all|title=Wojcicki: Memo could deter women from tech careers|last=Stangel|first=Luke|date=August 10, 2017|website=BizJournals|access-date=January 26, 2018|archive-date=June 26, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190626223558/https://www.bizjournals.com/bizwomen/news/latest-news/2017/08/wojcicki-emo-could-deter-women-from-tech-careers.html?page=all|url-status=live}} In February 2014, Wojcicki became the CEO of YouTube.{{cite news|last=Orescovic|first=Alexi|title=Google taps longtime executive Wojcicki to head YouTube|url=http://in.reuters.com/article/us-google-youtube-idINBREA141Y420140205|work=Reuters|date=February 5, 2014|access-date=July 5, 2021|archive-date=April 6, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190406005302/https://in.reuters.com/article/us-google-youtube-idINBREA141Y420140205|url-status=live}}{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2014/02/05/susan-wojcicki-youtube/|title=Google Ads SVP Susan Wojcicki Takes Over At YouTube|date=5 February 2014 |access-date=June 12, 2014|archive-date=June 26, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140626235401/http://techcrunch.com/2014/02/05/susan-wojcicki-youtube/|url-status=live}} She was named "the most important person in advertising",{{Cite web|title=Is This the Most Important Person in Advertising?|url=https://www.adweek.com/brand-marketing/most-important-person-advertising-147489/|access-date=2021-01-08|language=en-US|archive-date=2021-01-10|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210110213850/https://www.adweek.com/brand-marketing/most-important-person-advertising-147489/|url-status=live}} as well as named one of ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''{{'}}s 100 most influential people in 2015{{cite magazine |last=Grazer |first=Brian |url=http://time.com/3822770/susan-wojcicki-2015-time-100/ |title=The 100 Most Influential People |magazine=Time |date=April 16, 2015 |access-date=October 5, 2015 |archive-date=October 19, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161019030051/http://time.com/3822770/susan-wojcicki-2015-time-100/ |url-status=live }} and described in a later issue of ''Time'' as "the most powerful woman on the Internet".{{cite magazine |last=Luscombe |first=Belinda |url=http://time.com/4012832/meet-youtubes-view-master/ |title=Meet YouTube's Viewmaster |magazine=Time |date=August 27, 2015 |access-date=October 5, 2015 |archive-date=May 14, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170514202227/http://time.com/4012832/meet-youtubes-view-master/ |url-status=live }} That same year, she joined the board of [[Salesforce]].{{Cite web|title=Susan Wojcicki|url=https://www.salesforce.com/company/leadership/bios/bio-wojcicki/|access-date=2020-09-18|website=Salesforce.com|language=en|archive-date=2020-09-17|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200917172454/https://www.salesforce.com/company/leadership/bios/bio-wojcicki/|url-status=live}} She also serves on the board of [[Room to Read]],{{Cite web|title=Board of Directors|url=https://www.roomtoread.org/leadership-board/board-of-directors/|access-date=2020-09-18|website=www.roomtoread.org|archive-date=2020-10-28|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201028000034/https://www.roomtoread.org/leadership-board/board-of-directors/|url-status=live}} an organization that focuses on literacy and gender equality in education, and is a board member of [[UCLA Anderson School of Management]].{{Cite web|title=Susan Wojcicki ('89) - "The most important Googler you've never heard of"|url=https://blogs.anderson.ucla.edu/anderson/2011/02/susan-wojcicki-89-the-most-important-googler-youve-never-heard-of.html|access-date=2020-09-18|website=UCLA Anderson School of Management Blog|archive-date=2021-05-17|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210517204708/https://blogs.anderson.ucla.edu/anderson/2011/02/susan-wojcicki-89-the-most-important-googler-youve-never-heard-of.html|url-status=live}} After Wojcicki became the CEO of YouTube, the company reached 2 billion logged-in users a month{{Cite web|url=https://www.tubefilter.com/2019/02/05/youtube-2-billion-monthly-users/|title=YouTube Hits 2 Billion Monthly Users, As Number Of Channels With 1 Million Subscribers Doubled Last Year|date=2019-02-05|website=Tubefilter|language=en-US|access-date=2019-04-02|archive-date=2019-04-02|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190402043200/https://www.tubefilter.com/2019/02/05/youtube-2-billion-monthly-users/|url-status=live}} and that users were watching one billion hours a day.{{Cite news|url=http://mashable.com/2017/02/27/youtube-one-billion-hours-of-video-daily/#hs1RRV4k_Sqx|title=YouTube just hit a huge milestone|last=Hamedy|first=Saba|work=Mashable|access-date=2017-10-26|language=en|archive-date=2020-12-22|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201222213421/https://mashable.com/2017/02/27/youtube-one-billion-hours-of-video-daily/#hs1RRV4k_Sqx|url-status=live}}{{Cite news|url=http://fortune.com/2017/06/23/youtube-1-5-billion-monthly-users-mobile-video/|title=YouTube Claims 1.5 Billion Monthly Users in Latest Ad Sales Pitch|work=Fortune|access-date=2017-10-26|language=en|archive-date=2017-10-27|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171027025421/http://fortune.com/2017/06/23/youtube-1-5-billion-monthly-users-mobile-video/|url-status=live}} By 2021, YouTube had paid more than $30 billion to creators, artists, and media companies.{{Cite web|title=Letter from Susan: Our 2021 Priorities|url=https://blog.youtube/inside-youtube/letter-from-susan-our-2021-priorities/|access-date=2021-12-24|website=blog.youtube|language=en-us|archive-date=2021-12-23|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211223170515/https://blog.youtube/inside-youtube/letter-from-susan-our-2021-priorities/|url-status=live}} There are localized versions of YouTube in 100 countries around the world across 80 languages. Since she became CEO, YouTube's percentage of female employees has risen from 24 to nearly 30 percent.{{Cite news|url=https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2017/03/how-to-break-up-the-silicon-valley-boys-club-susan-wojcicki|title=Exclusive: How to Break Up the Silicon Valley Boys' Club|last=Wojcicki|first=Susan|work=The Hive|access-date=2017-10-26|language=en|archive-date=2017-08-18|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170818055811/https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2017/03/how-to-break-up-the-silicon-valley-boys-club-susan-wojcicki|url-status=live}} Wojcicki also emphasized new YouTube applications and experiences designed to cater to users interested in family{{Cite news|url=https://techcrunch.com/2015/02/23/hands-on-with-youtube-kids-googles-newly-launched-child-friendly-youtube-app/|title=Hands On With "YouTube Kids," Google's Newly Launched, Child-Friendly YouTube App|last=Perez|first=Sarah|work=TechCrunch|access-date=2017-10-26|language=en|archive-date=2019-06-26|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190626223616/https://techcrunch.com/2015/02/23/hands-on-with-youtube-kids-googles-newly-launched-child-friendly-youtube-app/|url-status=live}} gaming,{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2015/aug/26/youtube-gaming-live-website-apps|title=Google launches YouTube Gaming to challenge Amazon-owned Twitch|last=Dredge|first=Stuart|date=2015-08-26|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-10-26|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|archive-date=2015-09-06|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150906044745/http://www.theguardian.com/technology/2015/aug/26/youtube-gaming-live-website-apps|url-status=live}} and music{{Cite news|url=https://www.theverge.com/2015/11/12/9723496/youtube-music-app-offline-background|title=YouTube Music is here, and it's a game changer|work=The Verge|access-date=2017-10-26|language=en-US|archive-date=2017-10-27|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171027025337/https://www.theverge.com/2015/11/12/9723496/youtube-music-app-offline-background|url-status=live}} content. While CEO, the company developed 10 forms of monetization for YouTube creators, including channel memberships, merchandise, BrandConnect, and paid digital goods like Super Chat.{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=|title=10 ways to monetize on YouTube|url=https://blog.youtube/news-and-events/10-ways-monetize-youtube/|url-status=live|access-date=2020-05-31|website=YouTube Blog|language=en|archive-date=2021-08-03|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210803200146/https://blog.youtube/news-and-events/10-ways-monetize-youtube/}} She also launched YouTube's advertisement-free subscription service, [[YouTube Premium]] (formerly known as YouTube Red),{{Cite web|url=https://venturebeat.com/2015/10/21/google-wants-you-to-pay-9-99-per-month-for-ad-free-youtube/|title=Google wants you to pay $9.99 per month for ad-free YouTube {{!}} VentureBeat|website=venturebeat.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-10-26|date=2015-10-22|archive-date=2021-03-08|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210308075506/https://venturebeat.com/2015/10/21/google-wants-you-to-pay-9-99-per-month-for-ad-free-youtube/|url-status=live}} and its [[Over-the-top media services|over-the-top]] (OTT) internet television service [[YouTube TV]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-39124092|title=YouTube takes on cable with new service|last=Lee|first=Dave|date=2017-03-01|work=BBC News|access-date=2017-10-26|language=en-GB|archive-date=2021-03-08|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210308103826/https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-39124092|url-status=live}} In 2020, the company launched YouTube Shorts, its short-form video experience,{{Cite web|title=Building YouTube Shorts, a new way to watch & create on YouTube|url=https://blog.youtube/news-and-events/building-youtube-shorts/|access-date=2021-12-28|website=blog.youtube|language=en-us|archive-date=2021-06-10|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210610013637/https://blog.youtube/news-and-events/building-youtube-shorts/|url-status=live}} which recently surpassed 15 billion daily views.{{Cite web|title=Alphabet Q2 2021 earnings call|url=https://abc.xyz/investor/static/pdf/2021_Q2_Earnings_Transcript.pdf?cache=1b65cc3|url-status=live|access-date=2021-12-28|archive-date=2021-11-11|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211111033555/https://abc.xyz/investor/static/pdf/2021_Q2_Earnings_Transcript.pdf?cache=1b65cc3}} In September 2021, YouTube publicized that the company had surpassed 50 million Music and Premium subscribers, including trialers.{{Cite web|title=50 million|url=https://blog.youtube/news-and-events/50-million/|access-date=2021-12-24|website=blog.youtube|language=en-us|archive-date=2021-12-24|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211224174406/https://blog.youtube/news-and-events/50-million/|url-status=live}} The company also reported over 100 billion hours of global gaming content watched on the platform in 2020.{{Cite web|title=2020 is YouTube Gaming's biggest year, ever: 100B watch time hours|url=https://blog.youtube/news-and-events/youtube-gaming-2020/|access-date=2021-12-28|website=blog.youtube|language=en-us|archive-date=2020-12-08|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201208152602/https://blog.youtube/news-and-events/youtube-gaming-2020/|url-status=live}} Wojcicki tightened YouTube's policy on videos it regards as potentially violating its policies on hate speech and violent extremism.{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=|title=An update on our commitment to fight violent extremist content online|url=https://blog.youtube/news-and-events/an-update-on-our-commitment-to-fight/|access-date=2020-05-31|website=YouTube Blog|language=en-US|archive-date=2020-08-08|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200808070643/https://blog.youtube/news-and-events/an-update-on-our-commitment-to-fight|url-status=live}} The more stringent policies came after ''[[The Times]]'' showed that "ads sponsored by the British government and several private sector companies had appeared ahead of YouTube videos supporting terrorist groups" and several large advertisers withdrew their ads from YouTube in response.{{cite news|last=Alba|first=Davey|author-link=Davey Alba|title=YouTube's Ad Problems Finally Blow Up in Google's Face|url=https://www.wired.com/2017/03/youtubes-ad-problems-finally-blow-googles-face|newspaper=WIRED|date=25 March 2017|access-date=4 September 2017|archive-date=5 September 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170905052907/https://www.wired.com/2017/03/youtubes-ad-problems-finally-blow-googles-face|url-status=live}} The enforcement policies have been criticized as censorship.{{cite news|last=Hern|first=Alex|title=To censor or not to censor? YouTube's double bind|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2017/mar/21/youtube-advertisers-censorship|newspaper=theguardian|date=21 March 2017|access-date=29 August 2017|archive-date=8 August 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170808155124/https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2017/mar/21/youtube-advertisers-censorship|url-status=live}} Some YouTubers argue that the demonetization system is too strict, causing any remotely "edgy" content to get demonetized and in some cases even resulting in the creator's channel being removed.{{cite web|title=DO WE STILL TALK TO... ft. Maxmoefoe {{!}} Cold Ones| website=[[YouTube]] |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vkDWHiphPz4| archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211028/vkDWHiphPz4| archive-date=2021-10-28|url-status=live|access-date=2021-08-18}}{{cbignore}} During the controversy surrounding [[Logan Paul]]'s YouTube video about a person that committed suicide, Wojcicki said that Paul did not violate YouTube's three-strike policy and did not meet the criteria for being banned from the platform.{{cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2018/2/12/17006074/youtube-ceo-logan-paul-susan-wojcicki|title=YouTube's CEO says Logan Paul doesn't deserve to be kicked off the platform|last=Newton|first=Casey|date=12 February 2018|website=The Verge|access-date=18 October 2018|archive-date=18 October 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181018122247/https://www.theverge.com/2018/2/12/17006074/youtube-ceo-logan-paul-susan-wojcicki|url-status=live}} Wojcicki has emphasized educational content as a priority for the company, and on July 20, 2018, announced the initiative YouTube Learning, which invests in grants and promotion to support education focused creator content.{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=|title=Mid-year update on our five creator priorities for 2018|url=https://blog.youtube/inside-youtube/mid-year-update-on-our-five-creator/|url-status=live|access-date=2020-05-31|website=YouTube Blog|archive-date=2020-08-04|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200804030912/https://blog.youtube/inside-youtube/mid-year-update-on-our-five-creator}} On October 22, 2018, Wojcicki wrote that Article 13, as written in the [[Copyright Directive|European Union Copyright Directive]], would make YouTube directly liable for copyrighted content, and poses a threat to content creators' ability to share their work.{{Cite web|title=A final update on our priorities for 2018|url=https://blog.youtube/inside-youtube/a-final-update-on-our-priorities-for/|access-date=2021-12-08|website=blog.youtube|language=en-us|archive-date=2021-12-08|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211208065714/https://blog.youtube/inside-youtube/a-final-update-on-our-priorities-for/|url-status=live}} On April 15, 2021, Wojcicki was presented the “Free Expression Award” by the Freedom Forum Institute,{{Cite web|title=2021 Free Expression Awards|url=https://www.freedomforum.org/event/2021-free-expression-awards/|access-date=2021-12-05|website=Freedom Forum|language=en-US|archive-date=2021-12-05|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211205064314/https://www.freedomforum.org/event/2021-free-expression-awards/|url-status=live}} a nonprofit dedicated to advancing First Amendment freedoms.{{Cite web|title=About|url=https://www.freedomforum.org/about/|access-date=2021-12-05|website=Freedom Forum|language=en-US|archive-date=2021-12-05|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211205064316/https://www.freedomforum.org/about/|url-status=live}} The award ceremony was criticized for being sponsored by her own platform.{{cite web |last1=Zhao |first1=Christina |title=YouTube CEO Susan Wojcicki Gets Freedom Expression Award Sponsored by YouTube |url=https://www.newsweek.com/youtube-ceo-susan-wojcicki-gets-freedom-expression-award-sponsored-youtube-1585147 |website=Newsweek |date=20 April 2021 |publisher=NEWSWEEK DIGITAL LLC |access-date=13 November 2021 |archive-date=13 November 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211113095347/https://www.newsweek.com/youtube-ceo-susan-wojcicki-gets-freedom-expression-award-sponsored-youtube-1585147 |url-status=live }} == Advocacy == Wojcicki has been an advocate for several causes, including the expansion of paid family leave,{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/susan-wojcicki-paid-maternity-leave-is-good-for-business-1418773756|title=Paid Maternity Leave Is Good for Business|last=Wojcicki|first=Susan|date=2014-12-16|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|access-date=2017-10-26|language=en-US|issn=0099-9660|archive-date=2017-05-13|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170513234213/https://www.wsj.com/articles/susan-wojcicki-paid-maternity-leave-is-good-for-business-1418773756|url-status=live}} the plight of [[Syrian refugees]],{{Cite magazine|url=http://time.com/4373471/susan-wojcicki-world-refugee-day/|title=Susan Wojcicki: Refugees Are Trying to Escape Terror—Not Create It|magazine=Time|access-date=2017-10-26|archive-date=2017-08-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170830050457/http://time.com/4373471/susan-wojcicki-world-refugee-day/|url-status=live}} countering gender discrimination at technology companies,{{Cite news|url=https://money.cnn.com/2017/08/09/technology/youtube-ceo-gender-discrimination-response/index.html|title=YouTube CEO Susan Wojcicki on gender discrimination: It still hurts|last=Isidore|first=Chris|work=CNNMoney|access-date=2017-10-26|archive-date=2017-10-27|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171027025656/http://money.cnn.com/2017/08/09/technology/youtube-ceo-gender-discrimination-response/index.html|url-status=live}} getting young girls interested in computer science, and prioritizing computer programming and coding in schools.{{Cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/susan-wojcicki/tech-industry-gender-gap_b_9089472.html|title=Closing the Tech Industry Gender Gap|last=Wojcicki|first=Susan|date=2016-01-27|website=Huffington Post|language=en-US|access-date=2017-10-26|archive-date=2017-08-21|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170821021254/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/susan-wojcicki/tech-industry-gender-gap_b_9089472.html|url-status=live}} Wojcicki endorsed [[Hillary Clinton]] in the [[2016 United States presidential election|2016 U.S. presidential election]].Mandelbaum, R., [https://www.forbes.com/sites/robbmandelbaum/2016/09/23/more-business-leaders-sign-on-with-clinton/#4d1ff10750b0n More Business Leaders Sign On With Clinton] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161010204503/http://www.forbes.com/sites/robbmandelbaum/2016/09/23/more-business-leaders-sign-on-with-clinton/#4d1ff10750b0n |date=2016-10-10 }}, ''Forbes'', September 23, 2016. ==Personal life== Wojcicki married Google's director of product management Dennis Troper in [[Belmont, California]], on August 23, 1998.{{cite news |url=https://www.paloaltoonline.com/weekly/morgue/community_pulse/1998_Nov_11.WEDDI111.html |title=Weddings |newspaper=Palo Alto Weekly |date=November 11, 1998 |access-date=October 4, 2014 |archive-date=January 30, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150130082515/http://www.paloaltoonline.com/weekly/morgue/community_pulse/1998_Nov_11.WEDDI111.html |url-status=live }} They have five children. On December 16, 2014, ahead of taking her fifth maternity leave, she wrote an article in ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' about the importance of paid maternity leave. She is often quoted talking about the importance of finding the balance between family and career. In addition to her American citizenship,[{{cite web|title=Forbes Profile Susan Wojcicki|website=[[Forbes]] |url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/susan-wojcicki/|access-date=1 August 2017|archive-date=19 July 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170719140350/https://www.forbes.com/profile/susan-wojcicki/|url-status=live}} Wojcicki holds Polish citizenship through her father.{{cite web|last1=Kafka|first1=Peter|title=New YouTube Boss Susan Wojcicki Talks Talent, Music and M&A (Q&A)|url=http://recode.net/2014/08/12/new-youtube-boss-susan-wojcicki-talks-talent-music-and-ma-qa/|website=[[Recode|Re/code]]|access-date=16 December 2014|date=August 12, 2014|archive-date=17 April 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160417143437/http://recode.net/2014/08/12/new-youtube-boss-susan-wojcicki-talks-talent-music-and-ma-qa/|url-status=live}}[https://www.wsj.com/articles/susan-wojcicki-paid-maternity-leave-is-good-for-business-1418773756 ''Paid Maternity Leave Is Good for Business''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170513234213/https://www.wsj.com/articles/susan-wojcicki-paid-maternity-leave-is-good-for-business-1418773756 |date=2017-05-13 }}, The Wall Street Journal, 16 December 2014{{Cite web |url = http://next.gazeta.pl/next/7,151003,21560668,prezes-youtube-wlasnie-przyjechala-do-polski-a-to-dopiero-poczatek.html#BoxBizImg |title = Prezes YouTube właśnie przyjechała do Polski. A to dopiero początek dość niesamowitej historii |last1 = Hirsch |first1 = Rafał |website = next.[[Gazeta.pl]] |date = 28 March 2017 |language = pl |access-date = 28 March 2017 |archive-date = 16 May 2017 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20170516033536/http://next.gazeta.pl/next/7,151003,21560668,prezes-youtube-wlasnie-przyjechala-do-polski-a-to-dopiero-poczatek.html#BoxBizImg |url-status = live }} == Awards == Wojcicki was named #1 on [[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]'s ''New Establishment'' list in 2019.{{cite web|url=https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2019/10/new-establishment-list-2019|title=Vanity Fair New Establishment List 2019|website=[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]] |date=3 October 2019 |access-date=2019-11-23|archive-date=2019-10-08|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191008165856/https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2019/10/new-establishment-list-2019|url-status=live}} * In 2013, she was named #1 on the [[Adweek]] ''Top 50 Execs'' list, which recognizes the top media executives within an organization.{{cite magazine|date=October 28, 2013|title=The Top 50 Execs Who Make the Wheels Turn|url=http://www.adweek.com/news-gallery/top-50-execs-who-make-wheels-turn-153431#1-susan-wojcicki-1|magazine=Adweek|access-date=March 15, 2014|archive-date=February 9, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140209101227/http://www.adweek.com/news-gallery/top-50-execs-who-make-wheels-turn-153431#1-susan-wojcicki-1|url-status=live}} *In 2017, Wojcicki ranked #6 on Forbes' list of the ''World's 100 Most Powerful Women''.{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/susan-wojcicki/|title=Susan Wojcicki|work=Forbes|access-date=2017-11-15|language=en|archive-date=2017-10-25|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171025174639/https://www.forbes.com/profile/susan-wojcicki/|url-status=live}} * In 2018, she ranked #10 on Fortune's list of Most Powerful Women.{{cite magazine|url=http://fortune.com/2018/09/24/patti-davis-rihanna-fortune-most-powerful-women-2018-broadsheet-september-24/|title=Patti Davis, Rihanna, Fortune Most Powerful Women 2018: Broadsheet
